required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Whey or Casein - Liver Fat Reduction and Metabolic Improvement by Fast vs. Slow Proteins
clinical_study.official_title: Molke Oder Casein - Leberfettreduktion Und Stoffwechselverbesserung Durch Schnelle vs. Langsame Proteine (Whey or Casein - Liver Fat Reduction and Metabolic Improvement by Fast vs. Slow Proteins)

brief_summary.textblock:
High-protein diets have been recently demonstrated to effectively reduce insulin resistance, derangements of the lipid profile and liver fat content in subjects with moderately and severely impaired glucose metabolism and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (LeguAN, LEMBAS, DiNA-P, DiNA-D). The effects can be attributed to prolonged insulin secretion and improved second meal effect, higher energy expenditure by urea synthesis, suppression of glucagon or other mechanisms. Up to now, it is unclear, if proteins with slower or faster digestibility lead to differential results in these study designs. The proposed study will elucidate this question. The Investigators hypothesize, that slowly-digestible proteins induce a prolonged insulin plateau supporting the second-meal effect. The investigators also assume, that these dietary proteins lead to a markedly stronger short-term secretion of glucagon followed by desensitisation of this hormone release. Fast-digestible proteins, on the other hand, will presumably induce a smaller second-meal effect and do not inhibit a second rise of glucagon in a consecutive meal.
The investigators intend to study the effects of a 3-weeks high-protein diet in subjects with NAFLD (40 subjects without T2DM, 40 subjects with T2DM) on insulin resistance (mixed-meal tolerance tests; MMTT), second meal effect (second, consecutive MMTT on the same day) and liver fat content (MR spectroscopy) as well body-fat distribution (MR tomography). The investigators expect different results for slow protein (casein) and fast protein (whey), thus comparing both protein species. The two major clinical visits before and after the intervention period will also include fasting blood sampling for later analysis, full anthropometric assessment and a set of behavioral tests, investigating postprandial decision making processes.
All clinical assessments will be conducted in Charité (Lead: A.F.H. Pfeiffer). Psychobehavioral tests (Prof. Park), assessment of body fat distribution including liver fat (Dr. Machann) and measurements of amino acid levels throughout the meal tests (Prof. Rohn) are secondary work packages.

detailed_description.textblock:
High-protein diets have been recently demonstrated to effectively reduce insulin resistance, derangements of the lipid profile and liver fat content in subjects with moderately and severely impaired glucose metabolism and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (LeguAN, LEMBAS, DiNA-P, DiNA-D). The effects can be attributed to prolonged insulin secretion and improved second meal effect, higher energy expenditure by urea synthesis, suppression of glucagon or other mechanisms. Up to now, it is unclear, if proteins with slower or faster digestibility lead to differential results in these study designs. The proposed study will elucidate this question. The investigators hypothesize, that slowly-digestible proteins induce a prolonged insulin plateau supporting the second-meal effect. They also assume, that these dietary proteins lead to a markedly stronger short-term secretion of glucagon followed by desensitisation of this hormone release. Fast-digestible proteins, on the other hand, will presumably induce a smaller second-meal effect and do not inhibit a second rise of glucagon in a consecutive meal.
The investigators intend to examine the effects of a 3-weeks high-protein diet in subjects with NAFLD (40 subjects without T2DM, 40 subjects with T2DM) on insulin resistance (mixed-meal tolerance tests; MMTT), second meal effect (second, consecutive MMTT on the same day) and liver fat content (MR spectroscopy) as well body-fat distribution (MR tomography). The investigators expect different results for slow protein (casein) and fast protein (whey), thus comparing both protein species. The two major clinical visits before and after the intervention period will also include fasting blood sampling for later analysis, full anthropometric assessment and a set of behavioral tests, investigating postprandial decision making processes.
In order to identify the suitable dosage for protein loads in the 3-weeks intervention trial, the study follows a dose-finding assessment in 40 subjects (20 subjects with Metabolic Syndrome and T2DM; 20 subjects with Metabolic Syndrome without T2DM), which undergo six separate investigation days. On each day of the dose-finding assessment pre-trial one of the following dosages is used in a single oral protein tolerance test (5 g, 20 g and 30 g of whey or casein each). Subjects with NAFLD from this pre-study are eligible for the main trial.
Additional test will assess whether mixes of whey and casein in variable proportions induce different hormonal profiles of glucagon and insulin.
All clinical assessments will be conducted in the Dept. Endocrinology, Diabetes and Nutrition, Charité, Campus Benjamin Franklin (Lead: DIfE, A.F.H. Pfeiffer). Psychobehavioral tests (Prof. Park), assessment of body fat distribution including liver fat (Dr. Machann) and measurements of amino acid levels throughout the meal tests (Prof. Rohn) are secondary work packages.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)
study_design_info.masking_description: drinks and food supplements are provided in neutral boxes and containers supplements cannot be identified by visual appearance, taste, texture or odour

primary_outcome.measure: Liver fat change after three weeks
primary_outcome.description: absolute liver fat reduction after three weeks (MR spectroscopy)

primary_outcome.measure: change of 2-hours glucose levels in mixed meal test
primary_outcome.description: change of 2-hours glucose levels in mixed meal test

primary_outcome.measure: change of glucagon concentration pg/ml (ELISA) in mixed-meal test
primary_outcome.description: change of glucagon concentration (pg/ml) in mixed-meal test

primary_outcome.measure: change of insulin concentration (mIU/ml) in mixed-meal test
primary_outcome.description: change of insulin concentration (mIU/ml) in mixed-meal test calculated as (disposition index)

primary_outcome.measure: change of dynamic insulin sensitivity in mixed-meal test
primary_outcome.description: change of dynamic insulin sensitivity in mixed-meal test (Matsuda)

primary_outcome.measure: change of fasting insulin sensitivity in mixed-meal test
primary_outcome.description: change of fasting insulin sensitivity in mixed-meal test (HOMA-IR)

secondary_outcome.measure: change of insulin secretion in consecutive mixed-meal test after an initial breakfast MMT
secondary_outcome.description: change of insulin secretion in consecutive mixed-meal test after an initial breakfast MMT

secondary_outcome.measure: change of urea concentration in serum(mmol/l)
secondary_outcome.description: change of urea concentration in Serum (mmol/l)

other_outcome.measure: change in fasting amino acid concentration in blood
other_outcome.description: change in fasting amino acid concentrations determined by LC-MS in blood

other_outcome.measure: change in uric Acid concentration in Serum (µmol/l)
other_outcome.description: change in uric Acid concentration in Serum (µmol/l)

arm_group.description: Three weeks, twice daily supplementation with 30 g of whey protein (=60 g / day)
Three weeks, twice daily supplementation with 30 g of casein (=60 g / day)
Three weeks, twice daily supplementation with 30 g of pea protein (=60 g / day)
Three weeks, twice daily supplementation with 30 g of placebo (=60 g / day)

intervention.description: protein supplement, twice daily, 2 x 30 g of protein, 3 weeks of intervention; blinded to patients and personnel
Placebo supplement, twice daily, 2 x 30 g of placebo, 3 weeks of intervention; blinded to patients and personnel

criteria.textblock:
Subcohort 1 (n=40):
Inclusion Criteria:
- healthy
- with NAFLD
- 18-79 years
Exclusion Criteria:
- severe endocrine, gastrointestinal, metabolic, cardiovascular, pulmonary, inflammatory or psychiatric disorder
- active or recent relevant cancer
Subcohort 2 (n=40):
Inclusion Criteria:
- T2DM
- with NAFLD
- 18-79 years
Exclusion Criteria:
- severe endocrine, gastrointestinal, metabolic, cardiovascular, pulmonary, inflammatory or psychiatric disorder
- active or recent relevant cancer

contact.last_name: Andreas FH Pfeiffer, Prof. Dr. med.

responsible_party.investigator_full_name: Prof. Dr. med. Andreas F. H. Pfeiffer
responsible_party.investigator_title: Head Dept. Endocrinology, Diabetes and Nutrition
